awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  A Direct Lithium-Ion Battery Recycling Process Yielding Battery-Grade Cathode Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this SBIR Phase II project is to significantly improve the economics of lithium-ion battery (LIB) recycling, while minimizing its environmental impact. Direct recycling uses less energy and generates less pollutive waste and fewer emissions than alternative recycling approaches, while simultaneously producing more valuable products. The proposed project will advance the development of a recycling technology that will lower LIB cost, reduce the reliance of LIB production on the mining of expensive virgin metals, create a local supply of LIB materials, and facilitate the adoption of clean energy products (e.g., electric vehicles, grid storage). 

This SBIR Phase II project proposes to develop a cost-effective and scalable direct recycling process at a pilot-scale level. The proposed project will study LIB deactivation, component separation, purification, and regeneration processes that can be economically reproduced on a large scale. For example, a battery deactivation process that is quicker, safer, and cost-effective can be used in other waste management processes as well to discharge batteries. This project also will enable a better understanding of the key parameters of electrode extraction and purification processes able to preserve electrode chemistry and morphology. By focusing on the characterization of structure, morphology and electrochemical performance of the recycled materials, this project will lead to a more profound understanding of the effect of relithiation and heat treatment conditions on the quality of recycled cathode materials. Together, these studies will advance the knowledge and understanding of not only the process, chemistry, and mechanics behind the direct recycling process but also process optimization for a production-scale LIB recycling operation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this Phase II project is to scale-up a direct recycling process to efficiently separate, purify, and regenerate end-of-life (EOL) lithium-ion battery (LIB) cathode material, such as lithium cobalt oxide (LCO). Li Industries has successfully developed a recycling process at the laboratory scale that comprises: (1) battery deactivation, (2) battery sectioning, (3) electrode extraction, (4) cathode purification, and (5) cathode regeneration. In this Phase II project, the recycling process was further improved to handle kg-level LIB material in anticipation of a production-level process. A working kg-level process (e.g., can produce 3 kg of commercial-grade recycled cathode material/day), as well as plans for equipment and methods for a production-level direct recycling process has been successfully developed in this Phase II project.

In this project, the team at Li Industries focused on scaling up its core processes to kg-level processing. These kg-level processes, including the equipment needed to perform them, have been rendered operational, and kg-level cathode material, specifically lithium cobalt oxide (LCO), has been produced that is competitive with commercial level LCO materials.  In addition, other types of batteries with different chemistries supplied by US battery partners have been recycled through Li Industries’ direct recycling process. These recycled cathode materials are close to commercial virgin cathode materials and have been sent to partners for testing.

On the technical side, the team at Li Industries focused on further improving on its core processes: the deactivation, sectioning, extraction, purification, and regeneration steps to achieve a >3 kg/day production target.  A combined process that is able to reduce cathode product impurities for Cu, Al, and carbon has been successfully demonstrated.  Furthermore, an optimized recycling process was able to create kg level cathode material with a total impurity level less than the proposed target for this phase of the project. These results were achieved through the introduction of a modified purification process to isolate and remove impurities without affecting cathode composition or structure. This process is ready to be scaled up further to the kg level. Based on the results, at the end of the Phase II, The Li Industries team successfully completed the design of production-scale equipment and operation line for 300 metric tons/year production.

On the commercial side, the team focused on two primary goals in this project: (1) identify sources for consumer electronic EOL LIBs to support a scaled-up direct recycling process and (2) develop customer relationships for testing regenerated cathode material. In the Phase II, Li Industries successfully recycled US partners’ batteries in several formats to further assess the versatility of our recycling technology. The result of this test has been validated by US battery partners. In addition, Li Industries has further cultivated a partnership with current US battery sorting companies. Batteries were received from each of these companies for testing, and the results show that Li Industries is capable of processing most of the EOL lithium batteries, if not all, collected by these companies.
